bibl.title: Salfest S. Sylvester v. Stener S. Wenaas. Return to Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the matter of the application of Salfest S. Sylvester for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
div1.p: Comes now the Respondent, Stener S. Wenaas, and for return to the Writ of habeas corpus issued herein states, that he admits that the said petitioner is now in his custody and control, but denies that the said petitioner is now in his custody and control, but denies that the custody and control of said Petitioner by this respondent is in any manner illegal and unlawful, but alleges the fact to be that his custody abd control is in accordance with the laws of the State of Washington, and of the United States.

Respondent further states that during the summer and fall of 1898 the petitioner was in the employ as the agent of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which is a corporation, and as the agent of said Company While said Petitioner who in trail Court, until Dakota received into his possession certain money and property of said Company amounting to several hundred dollars, which sums he then and there unlawfully and feloniously embezzled and converted to his own use.

Respondent further shows that thereafter the said petitioner in order to avoid the laws of the State of North Dakota fled therefrom and became a fugitive from justice of said state and thereafter took refuge in the State of Washington.

Respondent further showeth that subsequent thereto the Governor of the State of North Dakota made due demand on the Governor of the State of Washington, which demand was accompanied by a requisition and other papers pursuant to law, demanding that the Governor of the State of Washingtion deliver over to the authorities of the State of North Dakota the said Petitioner as a fugitive from justice of the State of North Dakota as aforesaid; that the Governor of the State of North Dakota duly appointed this respondent, Stener S. Wenaas, as the agent
of said state to receive said petitioner on said requisition proceedings.

Respondent further showeth that said requisition as issued by the Governor of the state of North Dakota, together with the various and diverse papers thereunto attached was by this respondent delivered to the Governor of the State of Washington on or about the 26th day of December, A. D. 1898; That pursuant to the laws of the United States and of the State of Washington, and by virtue of the requisiton and demand as made upon him by His Excellency the Governor of the State of North Dakota, His Excellency, the Governor of the State of Washington, did on the 26th day of December, A. D. 1898 under his hand and the Seal of the State issue his certain Governor's warrant directing this respondent as the agent of the State of North Dakota to arrest said petitioner and convey him from this state to said State of North Dakota. That this respondent holds custody of the said petitioner under and by virtue of said warrant as aforesaid, a copy of which is hereto attached marked Exhibit A. and made a part hereof.

Respondent further shows that he denies each and every allegation contained in the petition of petitioner herein, except such as may he herein admitted, which are inconsistent with or in opposition to the statements and allegations in this return made.

Respondent further shows that heretofore and on or about the 28th day of December, A. D. 1898, the said petitioner appealed to the Superior Court of King County for a Writ of Habeas Corpus alleging that his distraints of liberty was at that time unlawful and that he was then unlawfully in the custody of this respondent; that to said proceedings this respondent made due and regular return; that the Superior Court on the trial and hearing of said matter coming up on the appliation of defendant, the present petitioner, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus and on respondent's return thereto, a open that the said respondend having said petitioner in his custody under and by virtue of the Governor's warrant, a copy of which is hereto attached marked Exhibit A., was in all things lawful and correct and in conformity to the laws of the State of Washington and of the United States.

That thereafter the said Petitioner in the Superior Court of King County appealed from said determination of the Superior Court to the Supreme Court of the State of Washington, and such proceedings were thereafter hadin the Supreme Court of the State of Washington in said cause that said last named court did on June 20th, 1899, render its judgment and opinion that the custody of the said petitioner was lawful, and affirmed the judgment of the Superior Court of King County to that effect directing that said petitioner be at once delivered to this respondent in conformity with the extradition proceedings and the warrant of the Governor of the State of Washington.

That thereafter the Remittitur from the Supreme Court of this state, together with the opinion of said court, was duly filed in the Clerk's office of King County, the original remittitur and the certified copy of the opinion of the Supreme Court of the State of Washington is now and here produced and exhibited in court. A copy of the opinion of he Supreme Court herein tx. B" a
div1.ab: Jas F McElroy Attorney for Respondent.
STATE OF WASHINGTON County of King.
div1.p: Stener S. Wenaas being first duly sworn, upon oath deposes and says: I am one of the respondents in the above entitled matter; as such I make the foregoing return and that the facts and statements set forth in the foregoing returns are true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 29th day of June, 1899.
div1.ab: Na D. Futton Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME, GREETING:
div1.p: WHEREAS, It has been represented to me by His Excellency JOSEPH M. DEVINE, Governor of the State of No.Dakota that Solvest A. Sylvester stands charged in said State with the crime of EMBEZZLEMENT committed in the County of Traill in said State and is a fugitive from the justice of said State and has taken refuge in the State of Washington;

AND WHEREAS, the said Governor of the State of North Dakota has pursuant to the constitution and laws of the United States demanded of me that I cause the said Solfest A. Sylvester to be arrested and delivered to Stener S. Wenaas, agents authorized to receive him into their custody and convey him back to said State of North Dakota.

AND WHEREAS, said representation and demand are accompanied by affidavits, complaint, information, indictment and warrant whereby the said Solfest A. Sylvester is charged with the said crime and being a fugitive from the justice of said State and having taken refuge in the State of Washington, which are certified by said Governor of North Dakota to be duly authenticated.

NOW, THEREFORE, I , J.R. ROGERS, Governor of the State of Washington, do hereby authorize and empower Stener S. Wenaas, the agent named in said demand, to take the said Solfest A. Sylvester wherever he may be found in this State, and transfer him to the line thereof at the expense of the State of North Dakota.
And I hereby command all civil officers within the said State of Washington to afford all needful assistance for the execution of this warrant.
IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the said State be affixed at Olympia, this twenty-sixth day of December, A. D. 1899.
(Seal of the State of Washington.)
div1.ab: WILL D. JENKINS, Secretary of State. By H. Alling, Chief Clerk.
div1.p: The appellant, Salfest A. Sylvester, sued out a writ of habeas corpus in the superior court of King County, whereby he sought to be discharged from the custody of Stener A. Wenaas. The cause and pretense of his arrest and detention he alleged to be a warrant issued by His Excellency, John R. Rogers, governor of the State of Washington, without first having the Givernor of North Dakota certify that an affidavit, if one has been made, stated a crime and was correct under the laws of said state, and that no indictment or affidavit required by law has been found or made in North Dakota. He further alleged that his imprisonment and restraint were illegal because, first, the governor of North Dakota has not certified that a crime is charged second, that no crime has been or is now charged or evidenced as is by law required, and, third, that the governor's warrant does not state facts sufficient to warrant petitioner's arrest and detention. The writ was duly served the respondent who thereupon made return thereto that he was the duly accredited agent of the State of North Dakota; that he denied that said petitioner was or is unlawfully restrained of his liberty; admits that the said petitioner is in the custody and control of the respondent; that said custody is in all things legal and in accordance with the constitution and laws of the United States, the states of North Dakota and Washington; that the respondent, as agent of the state of North Dakota, holds the said petitioner is his custody under and by virtue of a warrant for the arrest and extradition of said petitioner, issued by His Excellency J. R. Rogers, governor of the state of Washington, a copy of said warrant being hereto attached and made a part of this return, the original neverthless being now and here produced in court, upon the filing of this return the said petitioner moved the court to require the respondent to incorporate into and make a part of his return the representation and demand of the executibe of North

Dakota alleged in the warrant as accompanied by affidavits, complaint, information, warrant and indictment, so that said return should set forth the facts presented to the governor of the State of Washington upon which he issued his warrant. This motion was denied by the court and the appellant duly excepted to the ruling. Thereupon the appellant interposed a demurrer to the return on the ground that the same did not state facts sufficient to warrant a lawful imprisonment and detention of the petitioner. The demurrer was overruled by the court, and an exception taken; and the court thereupon dismissed the writ and entered an order fixing th bail of appellant in the sum of $500, and remanding him to the custody of the sheriff of King County until said bail be given, to be held by said sheriff at the expense of the state of North Dakota. From the judgment and orders of the court the petitioner appeals.

The respondent moves to dismiss the appeal upon the following grounds: I() a failure to serve and file briefs within the statutory time; (2) a lack of diligence in the prosecution of the appeal, and (3) that the order appealed from us not an appealable order and that the court has no jursidiction to entertain the appeal. Under the circumstances of this case we think there is no substantial merit in the first two grounds of the motion, and in regard to the point that the order remanding the appellant into custody is not appealable or subject to review by this court, and the case of In re Foye and that of In re Baker not yet reported establish the law of this state adversely to the contention of the respondent. For the reasons given more at large in those cases, the motion to dismiss is denied.

Following the rule laid down in the two cases above mentioned, we next proceed to determine the merits of this case, or, in other words, to ascertain whether, in fact, the appellant is and was illegally restrained of his liberty as alleged in his petition for the writ of habeas corpus. In this instance, it will be borne in mind, the papers accompanying the requisition of the governor of North Dakota were not produced at the hearing before the superior court,

and we are therefore necessarily limited to a consideration of the return of the respondent to the writ; and the question is, does the return, which is admitted to be true by appellant's demurrer, show facts sufficient to autorize the arrest and extradition of the appellant under article 4, section 2 of the constitution of the United States, and symbol5278 of the Revised Statutes of the United States, which provisions constitute the law governing the subject of interstate extradition. It seems to be the established law in this country that the executive authority of a state upon whom a demand has been made by the executive authority of another state for the rendition of a fugitive from justice, cannot be coerced by the courts to produce or exhibit the papers accompanying the requisition of the governor of the demanding state.
div1.ab: Church on Habeas Corpus, symbol 480; People v. Donohue, 84 N.Y.438.
div1.p: And that being true, it would seem logically to follow that one having the custody of an alleged fugitive from justice should not be obliged, on a hearing upon habeas Corpus, to produce such papers. In fact, this point was directly raised and passed upon adverse;y to the contention of the appellant in the Matter of Leary, 10 Benedict, 197; 6 Abbott's New Cases, 44. See also People v Donohue, 84 N.Y.438. The executive warrant in this case recities:

"Whereas it has been represented to me by His Excellency, Joseph M. Devine, Governor of the State of North Dakota, that Salfest A. Sylvester stands charged in said state with the crime of embezzlement committed in the county of Traill in said state, and is a fugitive from the justice of said state and has taken refuge in the State of Washington;

And whereas, the said Governor of the State of North Dakota has, pursuant to the constitution and laws of the United States demanded of me that I cause the said Salfest A. Sylvester to be arrested and delivered to Stener S. Wenaas, agents authorized to receive him into their custody and convey him back to said state of North Dakota

And wgereasm said representation and demand are acomoanied by affidavits, complain, information, indictment and warrant whereby the said Salfest A. Sylvester is charged with the said crime and being a fugitive from the justice of said state and having taken refuge in the State of Washinton, which are certified by said Governor of North Dakota to be duly authenticated.

Now, therefore, I, J. R. Rogers, Governor ofnthe State of Washington, do hereby authorize and empower Stener S. Wenaasm the agent named in said demand, to take the said Salfest A. Sylvester wherever he may be found in this state, and transfer him to the line thereof at the expense of the State of North Dakota.
And I hereby command all civil officers within said state of
Washington to afford all needful assistance for the execution of this warrant. * * *

This warrant, as we have before observed, was made a part of the respondent's return to the writ, and appellant's demurrer admits the truth of all of its material allegations, and, if it states all of the facts required by the constitution and laws of the United States to authorize the arrest of a fugitive from justice, then the a rest and detention complained os is not ellegal and appellant ought to be - remanded to the custody of the respondent to be transported to the state of North Dakota to answer to the charge there preferred against him. An examination of this warrant will show a compliance with all the conditions prescribed by symbol 5278 of the Revised Statutes of the United States. It clearly recites a demand by the governor of the State of North Dakota for the rendition of appellant as a fugitive from justice from that state; that the demand was accompanied by the papers therein specified; that it appears therefrom that appellant is charged in that state with the crime of embezzlement and that the papers accompanying the requisition were duly authenticated by the governor of the said state of North Dakota. None of the recitals are controverted by the appellant, and we think the warrant constitutes a sufficient authority for the arrest and extradition of the appellant
div1.ab: People vs. Donohue, supra People v. Pinkerton, 77 N.Y.245 Ex Parte Regal, 114 U.S. 642 Roberts vs. Reilly, 116 U.S. 80 Church on Habeas Corpus (2nd Ed.) 480 Matter of Clerk, 9 We nd.212
div1.p: The judgment and order of the lower court remanding the appellant was, in our opinion, correct and proper, and it is therefore affirmed; and it is ordered that the appellant be delivered to the respondent as the agent of North Dakota when he shall appear, and that in the mean time he be kept in the custody of the Sheriff of King County at the expense of said state.
div1.ab: We concur: Gordon, C. J. Fullerton, J. Dunbar, J. Reavis, J.
In Re Habeas Corpus of S. S. Sylvester Return to Writ
FILED IN THE U. S. CIRCUIT COURT, DIST. OF WASHINGTON.
